citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is an expired bottle of medication in use by the facility. A bottle of Safegard (febendazole) de-wormer expired in
October 2023. Expired or improperly labeled medications can be dangerous as the efficacy and potency cannot be
confirmed. If the medications are no longer effective, normally preventable diseases may become a problem. Correct by
ensuring that all medications are properly labeled and not expired, so the facility is able to use the appropriate methods to
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases. The licensee disposed of the expired medication at the time of the
inspection. Correct by: August 1, 2025, onward.

The facility is not creating records of acquisition for puppies. There were three litters totaling fourteen puppies for which
no acquisition records, commonly maintained on an APHIS 7005 form or a cage card, were created or maintained.
Accurate record keeping is essential so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the movement of dogs into and out
of the facility, especially in cases of loss or theft, and to help confirm adequate veterinary care was provided to all animals
at the facility. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the information
concerning dogs who are acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in possession or under their control; these records shall
include any offspring born by any dog while in their possession. Correct by: August 1, 2025, onward.

There was no written Program of Vet Care (PVC) available for review at the time of inspection. A written PVC outlines
instructions given by the Attending Veterinarian (AV) to the facility for how the care of the regulated animals regarding
physical examinations, vaccinations, fecal sampling, heartworm sampling, de-worming and preventative care such
grooming and checking teeth is to be performed. Lack of a program of veterinary care for dogs can lead to insufficient
routine veterinary care, and untimely diagnosis and treatment of the dogs. Each dealer must follow an appropriate
program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by the Attending Veterinarian.
Facilities must keep and maintain the written document and make it available for APHIS inspection. Correct by: August 1,
2025, onward.

There are no medical records available for review at the time of inspection for proof of fecal sampling and vaccination in
adult dogs for two of the vaccines required in §3.13(a)(3) of the Animal Welfare Act (distemper and parvovirus). The
facility representatives state the vaccinations were given and are believed to be current, however, they could not provide
documentation. The facility representatives were unsure if the fecal sampling had been performed within the last year.
Lack of appropriate documentation of medical records prevents APHIS inspectors from being able to accurately assess
compliance with the veterinary care requirements of the Animal Welfare Act. Dealers must keep copies of medical records
for dogs and make those records available for inspection. Correct by: August 1, 2025, onward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There is an expired bottle of medication in use by the facility. A bottle of Safegard (febendazole) de-wormer expired in 
October 2023. Expired or improperly labeled medications can be dangerous as the efficacy and potency cannot be 
confirmed. If the medications are no longer effective, normally preventable diseases may become a problem. Correct by 
ensuring that all medications are properly labeled and not expired, so the facility is able to use the appropriate methods to 
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases. The licensee disposed of the expired medication at the time of the 
inspection. Correct by: August 1, 2025, onward. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is not creating records of acquisition for puppies. There were three litters totaling fourteen puppies for which 
no acquisition records, commonly maintained on an APHIS 7005 form or a cage card, were created or maintained. 
Accurate record keeping is essential so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the movement of dogs into and out 
of the facility, especially in cases of loss or theft, and to help confirm adequate veterinary care was provided to all animals 
at the facility. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the information 
concerning dogs who are acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in possession or under their control; these records shall 
include any offspring born by any dog while in their possession. Correct by: August 1, 2025, onward. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There was no written Program of Vet Care (PVC) available for review at the time of inspection. A written PVC outlines 
instructions given by the Attending Veterinarian (AV) to the facility for how the care of the regulated animals regarding 
physical examinations, vaccinations, fecal sampling, heartworm sampling, de-worming and preventative care such 
grooming and checking teeth is to be performed. Lack of a program of veterinary care for dogs can lead to insufficient 
routine veterinary care, and untimely diagnosis and treatment of the dogs. Each dealer must follow an appropriate 
program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by the Attending Veterinarian. 
Facilities must keep and maintain the written document and make it available for APHIS inspection. Correct by: August 1, 
2025, onward.

3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There are no medical records available for review at the time of inspection for proof of fecal sampling and vaccination in 
adult dogs for two of the vaccines required in §3.13(a)(3) of the Animal Welfare Act (distemper and parvovirus). The 
facility representatives state the vaccinations were given and are believed to be current, however, they could not provide 
documentation. The facility representatives were unsure if the fecal sampling had been performed within the last year. 
Lack of appropriate documentation of medical records prevents APHIS inspectors from being able to accurately assess 
compliance with the veterinary care requirements of the Animal Welfare Act. Dealers must keep copies of medical records 
for dogs and make those records available for inspection. Correct by: August 1, 2025, onward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
